thread.title: Suburban Philly baseball coach charged with choking boy, 12
thread.title_full: Suburban Philly baseball coach charged with choking boy, 12

author: Julie Shaw
title: Suburban Philly baseball coach charged with choking boy, 12
text:
Suburban Philly baseball coach charged with choking boy, 12 Updated: March 23, 2017 — 1:46 PM EDT 41 Share 
Julie Shaw works on the Real Time News Desk for the Inquirer and the Daily News. During her 10-plus years at both papers, she has covered the courts, crime, immigration, and census stories. Arrow icon 
A Montgomery County high school baseball coach has been suspended after he allegedly choked a 12-year-old boy in Bucks County during a baseball training event last month for a youth league, authorities said Thursday. 
Kenneth Irwin, 52, Upper Moreland High School's baseball coach, was placed on administrative leave Wednesday, when school officials learned of the alleged incident, Upper Moreland School District Superintendent Robert Milrod said. 
Irwin has been charged with strangulation, disorderly conduct and harassment. NEWTOWN TOWNSHIP POLICE DEPARTMENT Kenneth Irwin. 
On Feb. 16, police were dispatched to the Newtown Athletic Club, at 120 Pheasant Run in Newtown, after a parent of the boy complained that during a baseball training event, Irwin had assaulted her son. 
Linda Mitchell, a spokeswoman for the athletic club, said Thursday that Irwin did not work for the club, but worked for a junior baseball group that rented space at the club. 
The alleged incident occurred in the club's Sports Training Center, not the main building, she said. 
After tryouts for a Newtown baseball league at the athletic facility, while players were cleaning up, Irwin, who was one of the coaches, allegedly tossed a plastic bucket at the boy, hitting him in the head, the Bucks County Courier Times reported. 
The boy then allegedly threw baseballs toward Irwin, hitting him in the leg, the newspaper reported, citing court documents. As the boy picked up another ball, Irwin allegedly rushed toward him, ordered him to drop the ball, pushed the boy, then put his hands on the child's neck and squeezed, the newspaper reported.
